text: A cardinal-nephew (;Cardinale, Hyginus Eugene. (1976). The Holy See and the International Order, p. 133. ;Burckhardt, Jacob et al. 1892. The Civilisation of the Renaissance in Italy,p. 107.) was a pope's relative -- a nephew -- who was raised to the rank of cardinal. The practice of creating cardinal-nephews originated in the Middle Ages. Cardinal-nephew was an office in the Curia of the Roman Catholic Church before 1692.The word nepotism comes from this practice; see Oxford English Dictionary citing Leti, Gregorio. (1673). Il Nipotismo di Roma, or, The History of the Popes Nephews: from the time of Sixtus IV, anno 1471, to the death of the late Pope Alexander VII, anno 1667 After the death of the reigning pope, the office of cardinal-nephew was vacated. The pope's cardinal-nephew was his chief assistant and confident."Roman Curia", Catholic Encyclopedia (2009); retrieved 2011-11-22. The man in this role was expected to act as if he were a relative of the pope; and sometimes -- often, he was in fact a member of the pope's extended family. After 1692, this office was banned by Pope Innocent XII in Romanum decet pontificem.Cardinale, p. 134. This role and function is now filled by the Vatican's Secretary of State. ==List of cardinal-nephews == Notable cardinal- nephews include many who would later become popes: *Gregory IX * Alexander IV * Adrian V * Gregory XI * Boniface IX * Innocent VII * Eugene IV * Paul II * Alexander VI * Pius III * Julius II * Leo X * Clement VII * Benedict XIII * Pius VII ==References== * Category:Religion-related lists
